p: By promoting a recent altitudinal migration of Bufotes balearicus from neighbouring, lower altitude sites, the ongoing climate warming engendered the unexpected syntopy at our study site. Support to this argument (the only alternative to recent translocation), comes from our models of the distribution of Bufotes balearicus in peninsular Italy, based on a set of known occurrences collected before year 2000, and projected to the average climate over the period 2007–2013. Indeed, our models indicated that the species’ presence above 1,200 MASL was highly improbable under pre-2000 climate, but became plausible during 2007–2013 ( Fig. 3). Furthermore, projecting the models under future climate projections for the time period 2070–2100 under different emission scenarios the general pattern remains unchanged ( Fig. 3). The reliability of the models was clearly confirmed by the field-validation procedure (see Materials and Methods). Indeed, our field searches of Bufotes balearicus at high-altitude sites of predicted presence in post-2000 projections were successful. We found a previously unreported site of occurrence within the Picentini Mountains (latitude: 40.8251°N; longitude: 14.9864°E; roughly 25 km south-east of the study site), thus confirming that upward migrations of Bufotes balearicus are ongoing, as predicted by our bioclimatic model (see also Zavadil & Roth, 1997).
